title: 106_s1699
content: The Act titled "Clean Water Infrastructure Financing Act of 1999" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to provide general authority for capitalization grants to accomplish the Act's purposes. The Clean Water Infrastructure Financing Act of 1999 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act by updating requirements for construction of treatment works and providing guidance for small systems to obtain assistance. After the enactment of this subsection, the Administrator will publish a manual to help small systems receive assistance under this title. The definition of a small system is a system serving a population of 20,000 or fewer inhabitants. SEC. 4. WATER POLLUTION CONTROL REVOLVING FUNDS. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to specify activities eligible for assistance from the water pollution control revolving fund of a State, including construction of treatment works, lake protection programs, and nonpoint source management programs. The water pollution control revolving fund of a State can be used for various activities, including estuary conservation, riparian area protection, improving water use efficiency, preventing water pollution, and acquiring land for mitigation requirements related to treatment works construction. The State's revolving fund is established for financial assistance in perpetuity. Fees collected can only be used for administering the fund. Additionally, disadvantaged communities may have an extended repayment period of up to 40 years or the project's expected life. The State's revolving fund provides financial assistance indefinitely, with fees used for fund administration. Disadvantaged communities may have a repayment period of up to 40 years or the project's expected life. Loan guarantees for innovative technology and administrative expenses are also addressed in the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. Disadvantaged communities may have a repayment period of up to 40 years or the project's expected life. Loan guarantees for innovative technology and administrative expenses are also addressed in the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. Technical and planning assistance for small systems is provided to improve wastewater treatment plant operations, including financial management, user fee analysis, budgeting, and facility maintenance. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to limit grant amounts and ensure consistency with planning requirements. Construction assistance from the water pollution control revolving fund is only provided for projects on the state's priority list. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allow states to charge a negative interest rate of up to 2 percent on loans to disadvantaged communities for water treatment projects. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act allows states to offer loans with a negative interest rate of up to 2 percent to disadvantaged communities for water treatment projects. The aggregate amount of these loans cannot exceed 20 percent of all loans made from the water pollution control revolving fund for the fiscal year. The term 'disadvantaged community' is defined as the service area of a publicly owned treatment works where the average annual residential sewage treatment charges meet affordability criteria established by the State. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends Section 607 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to allocate $3,000,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005.
